{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2996896,"name":"joemost","username":"joemost","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joemost/{size}/11114_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-23T14:25:13.061Z","cooked":"

Is there a preferred method for creating a turn in place trajectory?

looking at the examples calling trajectory generator, they wall want to drive some sort of curve

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2022-01-23T14:25:46.782Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":44,"reads":304,"readers_count":303,"score":280.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":401158,"topic_slug":"turn-in-place-trajectory","display_username":"joemost","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20003,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/turn-in-place-trajectory/401158/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2996926,"name":"NewtonCrosby","username":"NewtonCrosby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ed8c4c/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-23T16:49:22.119Z","cooked":"

I’m trying to wrap my brain around the terminology of trajectory in this case.

We’ve used MotionMagic in the CTRE motor controllers to have a rotational turn in place using a trapezoidal motion profile, we’ve also just used standard PID controllers to turn to a given angle.

I’m not understanding whether either of those would qualify as a turn-in-place trajectory.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2022-01-23T16:49:22.119Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":292,"readers_count":291,"score":73.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":401158,"topic_slug":"turn-in-place-trajectory","display_username":"NewtonCrosby","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31346,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/turn-in-place-trajectory/401158/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2996927,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-23T16:53:53.091Z","cooked":"

There’s currently no support in WPILib for generating instances of the Trajectory class that perform turn-in-place functions. We’ve discussed it a few times, and it’s on the radar for potential future additions.

For now, you can generate such a Trajectory manually with a TrapezoidProfile, or else use a ProfiledPIDController (or even a raw PIDController).

Look at the Trajectory class and the TrapezoidProfile class.

Can you imagine how you might be able to make an instance of TrapezoidProfile that represents a turn from one heading to another?

Can you see how you could turn such an instance of TrapezoidProfile into an instance of Trajectory that represents the same? (hint: what needs to happen to convert a TrapezoidProfile.State into a Trajectory.State?)

I guess to go from a TrapezoidProfile.State to a Trajectory.State you need to somehow convert from a velocity and position value to a pose with acceleration and speed. Not sure how though

I doubt you will find an example of this on github, unless another team has done this already (since it’s not a standard feature, it’s unlikely but not impossible). You’ll have to do the bulk of the implementation work yourself.

Ours from last year wasn’t a turn in place trajectory, but a separate command we wrote for turning in place.

TurnToAngleCommand.java
RobotContainer.java, see getFiveBallTrenchRunCommand()

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2022-01-24T16:38:35.740Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":24.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":401158,"topic_slug":"turn-in-place-trajectory","display_username":"Christopher149","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/SuperiorRoboworksTeam857/2021InfiniteRechargeAtHome/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/commands/TurnToAngleCommand.java","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":13},{"url":"https://github.com/SuperiorRoboworksTeam857/2021InfiniteRechargeAtHome/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/RobotContainer.java","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14984,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor"},"post_url":"/t/turn-in-place-trajectory/401158/13","custom_user_title":"FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2997397,"name":"Wolly :)","username":"wolly_efendi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wolly_efendi/{size}/165245_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-24T16:46:24.037Z","cooked":"

Is there a reason you need to use a trajectory? I think you could do a simple PID on gyro angle, or a ProfiledPID. Its been a while since I’ve touched a robot so I don’t have experience with using the Trajectories or anything like that. I’d imagine if you are driving trajectories before and/or after turning in place, you could create them as separate commands and run them sequentially.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2022-01-24T16:46:32.885Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":118,"readers_count":117,"score":23.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":401158,"topic_slug":"turn-in-place-trajectory","display_username":"Wolly :)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/controllers/profiled-pidcontroller.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Combining Motion Profiling and PID Control with ProfiledPIDController — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49878,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/turn-in-place-trajectory/401158/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2997400,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-24T16:54:24.969Z","cooked":"

So, a Trajectory.State contains the following information:

  • time
  • velocity
  • acceleration
  • pose
  • curvature

A TrapezoidProfile.State contains the following information:

  • time (implicit, passed into the sample function)
  • position
  • velocity

You need to take your starting Trajectory.State, and use the rotational positions and velocities from the TrapezoidProfile.States to generate a sequence of of Trajectory.States that represent the turn. The conversion might look something like (pseudocode):

for (time t in timesteps) {
  turnState = turnProfile.sample(t);
  nextPose = startPose
  nextPose.heading = turnState.position
  nextVelocity = 0; // turning in place
  acceleration = 0; //turning in place
  curvature = positive infinity
  trajectory.addState(new State(...args))
}
